summary:
Martijn Tellinga (The Netherlands, 1974) is an artist, composer and occasional performer. His practice occupies an intermedium between music composition, spatial installation and durational performance. Drawn from a reduced formalist-seeming vocabulary, his works pose reflections on the basic mechanisms of compositional form —often inquiring into modes of repetition, seriality and patterning—, and the musical agency of an evolving materiality and contextuality. They are commonly produced by means of some self-evolving system, a processual organisation, open-ended durational arrangement or site-specific dynamics, which in turn are tuned to propel perceptual, performative and social interactions. Much of his work is score-based and includes a wide variety of conceptual actions and chance operations, probing the emergent field between intended and accidental occurrences.

The spatial, performance and intervention-type works he produced in recent years, have increasingly aligned his output with emerging propositions for an expanded, post-media music practice. His current activities focus on how to read principles of musical structure, temporality and process to approach the multifaceted construct of installation, rendering musical work which activates site-adaptive movement and performative action, moving image and registrative techniques, text, and the architectural setting. Through such speculative musical spaces, an extended musicality is proposed: how can musical ideas travel between and convey through different mediums and situations, and function as a generative and experiential devise beyond sound and the concert setting? 

He received a Master’s degree in Sonology and multiple Stipends for Established Artists from the Mondriaan Fund. He is currently a funded PhD candidate at GradCAM in Dublin, Ireland. He presents worldwide, lectures and works in residence. He has articulated his artistic research through the development of courses around the spatial, processual and environmental modalities of sound informed practices. This led to visiting professorships at the Central Academy of Fine Arts in Beijing, China and ArtEZ Academy in Arnhem, The Netherlands.

He is one of the curator producers of the long running series DNK-Amsterdam. With DNK Ensemble he interprets and re-enacts seminal pieces on the edge of experimental music, performance art and installation, from the likes of Antoine Beuger, Cornelius Cardew, David Dunn, Dick Raaijmakers, Anthony McCall, David Tudor.

He lives and works in Amsterdam, Netherlands.

education.field_of_study: Structure Images, Sound Images, Formalized Music, Algorithmic Composition, Sound Art

profile_positions.title: artist, composer, performer

profile_positions.description:
DNK-Amsterdam is an artist collective actively producing concerts and exhibitions of media, sound and performance artists for close to 15 years. Functioning as an outpost in The Netherlands, we provide context and resonance for presentations of otherwise obscure and elusive artists in a precedent-setting program that appeals to a loyal audience of music and art lovers as well as the curious and the young. DNK-Amsterdam is produced and programmed by Seamus Cater, Koen Nutters and Martijn Tellinga.

As a performer within the series or as part of the DNK ensemble I've performed and interpreted works by David Dunn, Cornelius Cardew, Antoine Beuger, Stefan Thut, Steve Reich, Dick Raaijmakers, Luigi Nono, Alvin Lucier, Nutters/Avelas, Anthony McCall, George Brecht.

www.dnkdays.net
www.dnk-amsterdam.com
profile_positions.title: curator, producer, performer

company.name: Graduate School of Creative Arts and Media

profile_positions.company: Graduate School of Creative Arts and Media
profile_positions.description:
At Dublin Institute of Technology's GradCAM (Graduate School of Creative Arts and Media) I will pursue my PhD through practice-led-research. The project explores how an intermedia concept of musicality as a generative compositional device be developed through performative installation practice. This concept is animated, and animates, through scoring. The development of a score-based, event approach to installation is central to the study. It allows to speculatively probe the implications and possibilities raised by the question if and how non-sounding agencies can express musical form and musicality by entering into composition with both the sounding and the silent, the ‘musical’ and the ‘non-musical’.

My research will be supervised by Noel Fitzpatrick, Tim Stott and Connor McGarrigle. Final dissertation is planned for 2022.
profile_positions.title: Researcher Phd Candidate

profile_positions.description:
January/February 2018 and January/February 2020 I worked at BEAR/ArtEZ as guest teacher, supervising 2nd and 3rd year Undergraduate students during a 6-weeks project 'Scripting Space', in which students developed personal applications of scoring to advance their creative work. The project entails lectures, workshops, tutoring of individual projects and public presentation of results.

Besides these projects I do studio visits with students, discussing their work and ideas in preparation of upcoming exams or graduation.
profile_positions.title: visiting artist, lecturer

profile_positions.description: At the Central Academy of Fine Art's experimental media department and School of Design, I gave courses and lectures on Sound in Art and Performance to 3rd year Graduate and Post Graduate students. Introducing and discussing concepts, methods, artists and works, I aimed to provide students with a basic conceptual understanding and practical knowledge of both aesthetical and working principles and to create the first ability to autonomously implement these within their personal artistic practice. Additionally, I realised historic performance pieces, installation works and assignments with students during workshops. The courses covered subjects as Listening, Acoustics, Concrete Music, Sound Poetry, Spatialisation, Graphical and Prose scoring, Site Specificilty, Intervention Art, Audio Walks, Indeterminism and Experimental Composition.
profile_positions.title: guest lecturer

profile_positions.description: at 'The Modern Academy' (http://www.themodernacademy.org) I taught an intensive course ‘Spaces/Traces/Places’ for composers, artists and performers. The program entailed lectures, workshops, rehearsals and public performance of selected historic and contemporary pieces. It addressed topics such as; spatially mediated composition and performance, geometries of sound and space, process based music practice, self evolving forms, site specificity, music in unmusical places. The Modern Academy is an initiative of HKNME and supported by Hong Kong’s Goethe Institute, Spring Workshop, the Hong Kong Academy for Performing Arts and the University of Hong Kong
profile_positions.title: lecturer / coordinator

profile_positions.description: At Tsinghua's art department, I gave a course Sound in Art and Performance to 2nd year  Graduate students. Through lecturing and assignment I introduced concepts, methods, artists and works, including subjects like Listening, Acoustics, Concrete Music, Sound Poetry, Spatialisation, Site Specificity and Intervention.
profile_positions.title: guest lecturer

profile_positions.description: 'Nearly Not There'... A group show based on sound, performance and permutation, February 2015. Participating Artists, a.o.; Lucio Capece, Seamus Cater, Konzert Minimal, Brandon Labelle, Koen Nutters, Morten J Olsen, Gabriel Paiuk, Martijn Tellinga
profile_positions.title: participating artist and curator/producer 'Nearly Not There'

profile_positions.description: In 1956, a studio for electronic music was opened within the acoustics department of Philips Research Laboratories. The artistic highlight of the this studio was the 'Poème électronique', an automated performance with image, color, and electronic music in a building designed by Iannis Xenakis for the Brussels World Fair in 1958. Philips decided in 1960 that the Research Laboratories could no longer house a studio which was becoming a workplace for composers and less a means of meeting direct corporate needs. The studio was transferred to the Utrecht University. Since 1961, Gottfried Michael Koenig came regularly to the Netherlands as a speaker during the yearly Gaudeamus Music Week in Bilthoven where he also started a course on electronic music in the garden house of the Walter Maas House. In 1964, Koenig became artistic director of the Institute of Sonology. In 1986,  it was incorporated in the Royal Conservatory in the Hague. In addition to the one-year course, a four-year conservatory major and a two-year Masters are now offered.
profile_positions.title: external advisor / exam committee member for Bachelor's program

profile_positions.description: Either by myself or with Radboud Mens, I've produced series of radio programs on a wide variety of sounds, aesthetics, people, labels, Fluxus, Audio Art
profile_positions.title: radio maker
